quotes: Executive Director of the McCain Institute In office March 14, 2021 – May 2, 2022
Executive Director of the World Food Programme In office April 4, 2007 – April 5, 2012
16th Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business, and Agricultural Affairs In office August 23, 2005 – April 4, 2007
She served as Ambassador and Deputy U.S. Trade Representative under President George Bush, covering all Asia, Africa and Intellectual Property, Technology and Agriculture from 2001-2005.
Sheeran served as the seventh president and CEO of Asia Society from 2013 to 2020.
Kofi Annan in November 2006.
On July 26, 2021 she was appointed President of Canoo (NASDAQ: GOEV)
She earned a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Colorado at Boulder in 1976.
In April 2008, Sheeran attracted worldwide attention with a speech in London warning about an impending worldwide food crisis, which she likened to a "silent tsunami"
In January 2009, Sheeran called on the government of Israel to allow more UN food aid to the people in Gaza during the conflict there.
In January 2012, Sheeran announced that she would assume the role of Vice Chairman of the World Economic Forum upon completing her term
at WFP in 2012.
appointed on June 20, 2017, representing UN Secretary General António Guterres
when he publicly apologized for the UN's role in Haiti's cholera epidemic in December 2016.
and left in 2015 upset that the international community failed to 'acknowledge the fact that we have in Haiti the largest epidemic in the Western Hemisphere.'
Sheeran got her start in journalism in 1976 with the New York News World
In 1982, she moved to News World's new sister paper, The Washington Times.
Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), founded through a partnership between the Rockefeller Foundation and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in 2006
In 2011, Forbes named her the world's 30th most powerful woman;
She was a Fisher Fellow at the Harvard Kennedy School Belfer Center in 2013.
American diplomat Josette Sheeran selected to head U.N. World Food Program, U.N. announces, International Herald Tribune, November 7, 2006 (Associated Press item)

Sheeran was also the United Nations's Special Envoy for Haiti, successfully leading efforts to end a devastating cholera epidemic there.

While there, she helped found and advance global initiatives encompassing global, regional, and industry agendas such as Grow Africa, launching new technologies and attracting over $300 million in private sector investment to end aid dependency and tackle hunger and malnutrition in Africa.
In the role she introduced the first block chain to deliver food and cash to war zones such as Syria, and successfully negotiated access into Somalia, North Korea and Libya.

Sheeran was born in Orange, New Jersey, and is one of six siblings.
In April 2008, Sheeran attracted worldwide attention with a speech in London warning about an impending worldwide food crisis, which she likened to a "silent tsunami"
and lobbied the United States and other governments to give more aid to the world's poor.
In January 2009, Sheeran called on the government of Israel to allow more UN food aid to the people in Gaza during the conflict there.
